common_issues.title: VS Code Extension Sign-In Issue with Pieces OS 12.1.0
common_issues.description: Users are experiencing sign-in issues with the Pieces VS Code extension despite having Pieces OS 12.1.0 running.  The extension repeatedly prompts for sign-in and displays an error message upon attempting to sign in. This might be related to standard account limitations.  Further investigation is needed to determine the root cause and solution.

related_issues.title: Pieces in VS code
related_issues.text: Pieces in VS code ### Checked for Existing Issues? - [x] Yes, I have checked existing issues and cannot find one related to this. ### Software Desktop Application, VS Code ### Operating System / Platform Windows ### Your Pieces OS Version 12.1.0 ### Early Access Program - [ ] Yes, this is related to an Early Access Program feature. ### Kindly describe the bug and include as much detail as possible on what you were doing so we can reproduce the bug. Hello, I have an updated version of Pieces OS 12.1.0, and Pieces Desktop 4.3.1. I try to use the Pieces extension in VS code, but always asking me to sign in and run Pieces OS (what is running on startup automaticly) I clicked sing in but I only receive an error: I dont know If this is related to that I have only the standard account or not. Thank you for your help and feedback. Matthew Error generating summary: 404 Publisher Model `projects/pi3c3s-cloud-server/locations/us-east1/publishers/google/models/gemini-pro` was not found or your project does not have access to it. Please ensure you are using a valid model version. For more information, see: https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/learn/model-versions

recommendations: Investigate the VS Code extension sign-in issue with Pieces OS 12.1.0. Start by checking if standard accounts have the necessary permissions.  Consider adding more detailed logging to the extension to help diagnose the problem.
Prioritize resolution of issue #797, "Pieces in VS code", as it has the highest activity level and relates to the common sign-in problem.
